pull.title: p2p: always set nTime for self-advertisements
pull.body: This logic was recently changed in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/0cfc0cd32239d3c08d2121e028b297022450b320 to overwrite `addrLocal` with the address they gave us when self-advertising to an inbound peer. But if we don't also change `nTime` again from the default `TIME_INIT`, our peer will not relay our advertised address any further.

events.body:
utACK 65749ee3933898b54a77443e647ed5c1d12e0f99
good catch. could be a good functional test?

> good catch. could be a good functional test?

I think that would be hard, because the local addresses in the functional tests are unroutable, so nodes don't self-advertise there. There is even the workaround of the `-addrmantest` parameter used in `p2p_node_network_limited.py` for this, but that just returns a fixed addr so the code changed here isn't executed.
However, the unit test `net_tests/get_local_addr_for_peer_port` covers this (and would fail without the update in this PR). Before, it would just check that the expected and actual CAddress have a default-initialized nTime.

Concept ACK

The proficiency of the engineers is just astonishing in this community (@mzumsande)! How the hell did you catch this?

> The proficiency of the engineers is just astonishing in this community (@mzumsande)! How the hell did you catch this?

Thank you! Pretty much by chance - I was reviewing #25303 and while looking at this [commit msg](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25303/commits/00001e57fe74c061aa9cbc72b07252335cb566e0) I was wondering if it was possible to somehow have addresses with default-initialised nTime in addrman or addr relay  - that's how I stumbled upon this.

events.message:
p2p: always set nTime for self-advertisements

If we self-advertised to an inbound peer with the address they gave us,
nTime was left default-initialized, so that our peer wouldn't relay it
any further along.

issue.title: net processing: Move CNode::nServices and CNode::nLocalServices to Peer
issue.body:
Another step in #19398. Which services we offer to a peer and which services they offer to us is application layer data and should not be stored on `CNode`.

This is also a prerequisite for adding `PeerManager` unit tests (See #25515).

comments.body:
Here we want to preserve the `nTime` as it was before the `addrLocal =` assignment. So it is better to use `addrLocal.nTime` instead of `GetAdjustedTime()` because using the latter seeps knowledge that `GetLocalAddress()` has set `nTime` to `GetAdjustedTime()` and so if that is changed to set it to e.g. `GetFooTime()`, this line would have to be changed too.

Luckily `CAddress` has a constructor that takes `nTime` which is handy:

```cpp
addrLocal = CAddress{pnode->GetAddrLocal(), addrLocal.nServices, addrLocal.nTime};
```

These changes would not be needed if the test below is fixed to just compare the address and port - that is/was the intention, but in the last check:

```cpp
BOOST_CHECK(*chosen_local_addr == peer_us);
```

it ends up comparing to `CAddress` objects which also compares time and services. That is not intended. Better change it to:

```cpp
BOOST_CHECK(static_cast<CService>(*chosen_local_addr) == peer_us);
```

or even more obvious:

```cpp
BOOST_CHECK(static_cast<CService>(*chosen_local_addr) == static_cast<CService>(peer_us));
```

Wouldn't it be better to have the test compare the entire advertised `CAddress`, especially with the difficulties of writing functional test for self-advertisements? 
I know it is not the main intention for this test, but I think it is nice to have this tested on the side, especially with the footgunny `CAddress(CService, ServiceFlags)` ctor that is used so frequently, probably to avoid `int64_t`  / `uint32_t` compiler warnings when inserting a `int64_t` time into the full ctor with `nTime`.
So maybe it would be better to instead also raise the earlier check to the Level of `CAddress`?
Good suggestion, will do with the next push.

I took your suggestion to modify, and also changed the check for `expected` to the level of `CAddress`. I think it's natural for a unit test of a function that returns an object to check the entire object is as expected, and not just parts of it, especially if it's just two more fields and a (thorough) separate test that would have caught this issue would have required to replicate some of the port stuff in order to also get to the branch where nTime was left default-initialized.
